skos.definition: Acute kidney injury caused by obstruction of urinary outflow at any level from the renal pelvis to the urethra, requiring bilateral obstruction (or unilateral in a solitary kidney) to cause significant renal dysfunction.
skos.scopeNote: Accounts for 5-10% of AKI cases; only type of AKI that is readily reversible if diagnosed and treated early

content.title: Post-renal Acute Kidney Injury
content.summary: Post-renal AKI results from obstruction of urinary outflow, which must be bilateral (or affect a solitary functioning kidney) to cause significant renal dysfunction. It is the most readily reversible form of AKI when diagnosed and treated promptly through relief of obstruction.
key_points: Requires bilateral obstruction or obstruction of a solitary kidney
Renal ultrasound is initial diagnostic test - look for hydronephrosis
Absence of hydronephrosis does not exclude obstruction (early, dehydrated, encased kidney)
BPH is most common cause in elderly men
Prompt relief of obstruction is definitive treatment
Post-obstructive diuresis may occur after relief - monitor closely
Urinary indices vary and are not reliable for diagnosis
content.statement: Post-renal acute kidney injury occurs when urinary outflow is obstructed, causing back-pressure that impairs glomerular filtration. Unlike other forms of AKI, it is uniquely amenable to mechanical intervention, and prompt relief of obstruction can lead to complete recovery if treated before permanent parenchymal damage occurs.

explanation.intuition: Think of post-renal AKI like a backed-up plumbing system - when the drain is blocked, pressure builds up backward until no new water can enter the system. In the kidney, obstruction causes the renal pelvis and calyces to dilate (hydronephrosis), and the back-pressure eventually opposes glomerular filtration.
explanation.key_insight: Post-renal AKI is the only form of AKI where the primary treatment is mechanical rather than medical. Ultrasound can rapidly diagnose hydronephrosis, and relief of obstruction (catheterization, stent, or nephrostomy) can be performed emergently. The key is to think of obstruction early in the differential.
explanation.technical_details: Acute obstruction initially increases intratubular pressure, which opposes glomerular filtration pressure and reduces GFR. This triggers afferent arteriolar vasoconstriction via tubuloglomerular feedback and angiotensin II. Prostaglandins and nitric oxide provide initial compensation. Prolonged obstruction leads to tubulointerstitial fibrosis and irreversible nephron loss. Complete obstruction causes more rapid damage than partial obstruction.

definitions_glossary.hydronephrosis: Dilation of the renal pelvis and calyces due to obstruction of urinary outflow
definitions_glossary.hydroureter: Dilation of the ureter proximal to the site of obstruction
definitions_glossary.post_obstructive_diuresis: Massive urine output (>200 mL/hr) after relief of chronic bilateral obstruction; may cause dehydration
definitions_glossary.benign_prostatic_hyperplasia: Enlarged prostate causing bladder outlet obstruction; most common cause in elderly men
definitions_glossary.urolithiasis: Kidney stones; common cause of unilateral obstruction (bilateral if staghorn or ureteral)
definitions_glossary.neurogenic_bladder: Bladder dysfunction from nerve damage causing urinary retention and overflow
definitions_glossary.retroperitoneal_fibrosis: Rare condition causing ureteral encasement and bilateral obstruction
definitions_glossary.bladder_outlet_obstruction: Obstruction at the level of the bladder neck or urethra
definitions_glossary.ureteral_stent: Tube placed from kidney to bladder to relieve ureteral obstruction
definitions_glossary.nephrostomy_tube: Percutaneous tube draining urine directly from renal pelvis
definitions_glossary.foley_catheter: Urinary catheter for bladder drainage; first-line for bladder outlet obstruction
definitions_glossary.postvoid_residual: Urine remaining in bladder after voiding; elevated in obstruction
definitions_glossary.anuria: Complete absence of urine output; suggests complete bilateral obstruction
definitions_glossary.staghorn_calculus: Large branching kidney stone filling the renal pelvis; can cause obstruction

pathophysiology.mechanism: Obstruction causes increased intratubular and intrapelvic pressure, which opposes glomerular filtration. Initially, prostaglandins cause afferent dilation to maintain GFR, but sustained obstruction leads to vasoconstriction, tubular atrophy, and interstitial fibrosis.

anatomic_levels.bladder_outlet: BPH, prostate cancer, bladder neck contracture, urethral stricture
anatomic_levels.unilateral_ureteral: Stone, tumor, blood clot (only causes AKI if solitary kidney)
anatomic_levels.intratubular: Crystal deposition (uric acid, indinavir), cast nephropathy

timeline.acute: Hours to days - GFR decline reversible with relief
timeline.subacute: Days to weeks - some tubular damage but still recoverable
timeline.chronic: Weeks to months - irreversible fibrosis and nephron loss

symptoms: Anuria (complete obstruction) or fluctuating urine output
Flank pain (acute ureteral obstruction, e.g., stone)
Urinary frequency, urgency, hesitancy, weak stream (BPH)
Lower extremity edema (retroperitoneal mass, IVC compression)
signs: Enlarged prostate on digital rectal exam

serum: Metabolic acidosis (type IV RTA in chronic obstruction)
urine: Urinary indices are NOT reliable in post-renal AKI
Hematuria common with stones or tumor

renal_ultrasound.sensitivity: 90-95% for obstruction, but false negatives occur early or with dehydration

CT_scan.advantages: Better anatomic detail, can identify cause and level of obstruction
CT_scan.considerations: Non-contrast CT for stones; CT urography if tumor suspected

other: Postvoid residual - elevated in bladder outlet obstruction
Retrograde pyelogram - if antegrade not possible

diagnostic_pitfalls: Hydronephrosis may be absent in early obstruction (<24-48 hours)
Renal ultrasound normal â‰  no obstruction

immediate: Place Foley catheter for bladder outlet obstruction

relief_of_obstruction.bladder_outlet: Foley catheter or suprapubic catheter if urethral impassable
relief_of_obstruction.definitive: Treatment of underlying cause (TURP for BPH, stone removal, tumor treatment)

post_obstructive_care.diuresis_monitoring: Monitor urine output every 1-2 hours after relief of chronic obstruction
post_obstructive_care.fluid_replacement: Replace 50-75% of urine output with IV saline if diuresis >200 mL/hr
post_obstructive_care.electrolyte_monitoring: Check potassium, sodium, magnesium every 6-12 hours during diuresis
post_obstructive_care.avoid_over_replacement: Physiologic diuresis is appropriate; avoid perpetuating diuresis with excessive fluids

prognosis.reversibility: Excellent if obstruction relieved within 1-2 weeks
prognosis.chronic_obstruction: Irreversible damage after 6-12 weeks of complete obstruction
prognosis.recovery_predictors: Shorter duration, incomplete obstruction, absence of infection

learning_objectives: Define post-renal AKI and explain why bilateral obstruction is required
List common causes of urinary tract obstruction by anatomic level
Describe the role of renal ultrasound in diagnosing post-renal AKI
Recognize clinical scenarios suggesting obstructive uropathy
Outline the management of post-obstructive diuresis
Explain the timeline for reversibility of obstructive nephropathy
clinical_pearls: Always check for obstruction with ultrasound in any unexplained AKI - it's the most treatable cause
Anuria (no urine at all) is rare in pre-renal and intrinsic AKI - think obstruction
Normal ultrasound doesn't rule out early obstruction - repeat in 24-48 hours if high suspicion
Post-obstructive diuresis can cause severe volume depletion - monitor closely for 24-48 hours
BPH is often subclinical until acute urinary retention precipitates AKI
Bilateral ureteral obstruction from malignancy may present with anuria

common_question_stems: Elderly man with BPH presents with anuria and distended bladder
Patient with cervical cancer and bilateral hydronephrosis
Man with kidney stone and solitary kidney develops AKI
Patient with massive diuresis after Foley catheter placement
exam_tips: Post-renal = always check ultrasound for hydronephrosis
Anuria strongly suggests complete bilateral obstruction
Post-obstructive diuresis - replace ~50% of output, monitor electrolytes

teaching_cases.scenario: 78-year-old man with BPH presents with 2 days of oliguria, suprapubic discomfort, Cr 5.6 mg/dL (baseline 1.2)
teaching_cases.key_findings: Distended bladder on exam, ultrasound shows bilateral hydronephrosis, 1200 mL drained with Foley
teaching_cases.diagnosis: Post-renal AKI from bladder outlet obstruction (BPH)
teaching_cases.management: Foley catheter drainage, monitor for post-obstructive diuresis, urology referral for TURP

citations.title: Obstructive nephropathy: from mechanical disturbance to immune activation

evidence.confidence_rationale: Based on established nephrology and urology literature and guidelines

sources.source: KDIGO Clinical Practice Guideline for Acute Kidney Injury
sources.relevance: Primary reference for AKI classification and management
Comprehensive urology reference for obstructive uropathy
